titleStmt.title: Determination of Unknown Particle Charges in a Thunder Cloud Based Upon Detected Electric Field Vectors

analytic.title: Determination of Unknown Particle Charges in a Thunder Cloud Based Upon Detected Electric Field Vectors

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Climatological data about thunderstorms is traditionally collected by balloons or planes traveling through the storm along straight tracts. Such data lends itself to simple 2D representations. The data described here was gathered by a sail plane spiraling in an updraft within a thundercloud. The more complex organization of data samples demands more complex representation methods. This paper describes a system developed using vtk to explore such data. The data consists of several scalar values and a set of vector values associated with positional data on the measuring devices. The goal of this visualization is to explore the location of point charges suggested by the electro magnetic field vectors and determine if any correlation exists between the point charge location and standard cloud microstructure scalar measurements such as temperature. There are several problems associated with visualizing this rather unique set of data. They stem from the fact that the data is a sparse spiraling sample of scalars and vectors. The system allows the track of the plane to be displayed as a line, a tube, or a ribbon; scalar values can be displayed as transparent isosurfaces; the vector data as an arrow plot along that track, given a color that is constant, based on orientation, or related to the value of a scalar. Any combination of methods can be used to display the data. A single primitive can be overloaded in many ways, or several different variables can all be displayed simultaneously.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Standard climatological methods of collecting thunderstorm data involve releasing balloons into or flying aircraft through clouds [KES83]. This gives repeated horizontal or vertical Dan Drake <dwdrake@olemiss.edu> Thomas Simpson <simpson@olemiss.edu> Larry Smithmier <larry_smithmier@earthling.net> Penny Rheingans <rheingans@cs.olemiss.edu> (601) 232-7396 Computer and Information Science 302 Weir Hall UNIVERSITY, MS 38677 tracks of measurements easily displayed in 2D plots. Our data set contains vector and scalar data collected by a sail plane spiraling within and around a thunderstorm complex. It contains a measure of the standard microstructure components of the storm system (updraft speed, temperature, and liquid water content [ROG89]) as well as vector data relating to a detected electric field. The track of the plane becomes convoluted in one region, obscuring the data of interest when standard (to climatologists) methods were used. More complicated flight paths demand different representation techniques. One main goal in the analysis of this data is to approximate the position of point charges found within the thunder cloud and relate these to the scalar values.

Existing representation methods for multivariate vector data include: particle tracing [AND93], illuminated stream lines [ZÃ–C96], semi-transparent Gaussian splats [SCH96], line integral convolution [FOR94], and arrow plots [SCH96]. These methods generally are concerned with displaying a 3D vector field or showing vectors close to a surface while we only have vectors along a single path. The sparse nature of the vector field data demands a different approach.

The package described here displays atmospheric data interactively using a variety of techniques, including: a line, tube, or ribbon for the positional data; color, tube diameter, ribbon width, and semi-transparent Gaussian splats to represent scalar data; and an arrow plot to represent the vector field data. The vectors can be colored constantly, according to orientation, or according to orientation with a filter designed to emphasize vectors with a particular orientation. The emphasis filter de-saturates vectors pointing away from the direction of interest.

div.head: Background
div.p: The sail plane flew up into the cloud in a spiral pattern, measuring updraft speed, temperature, liquid water content, and vector data relating to the detected electric field. The position, true air speed, and heading were also recorded about the plane as it made the flight. The plane did some slow curves in a thermal until it reached the edge of the cloud and then started tighter, highly erratic curves through the cloud itself.

div.head: Representations
div.p: We constructed a system for displaying sparse scalar and vector data along a track. Because of the importance of interactivity in understanding the complex track, methods with modest rendering requirements were emphasized.

A flexible set of representational models was included to facilitate exploration. Methods provided to represent scalar values along the track include coloring the track, following the track with a tube of varying radius, and following the track with a ribbon of varying width.
Semi-transparent 3D Gaussian splats were also investigated as a method of representing scalar values. The vtk Gaussian splat method creates a volume from a set of arbitrarily

We used the Visualization Toolkit (vtk) developed by located sample points by adding a 3D Gaussian splat to the volume Schroeder, Martin, and Lorensen [SCHR96] as a basis for our for each sample point. The Gaussian distribution of each splat is scaled by the associated scalar value. We create isosurfaces from this volume data around the track plot. Multiple isosurfaces are generated rather than doing volume rendering to preserve interactive rendering speeds. The vector data is displayed using an arrow plot, colored either a constant color, a color based on a scalar, or a color based on orientation and verticality. Orientation refers to the projection of the vector into the x,z plane (parallel to the ground) and verticality refers to the part of the vector orthogonal to the x,z plane.
Even with the 3D plot, the vector data along the spiral requires interactivity for a viewer to be able to perceive clearly the orientation and magnitude of the vectors. The need for interactivity

The goal of location of point charges suggested by the electro magnetic field vectors requires isolation of specific vectors or vectors meeting specific criteria. We developed a filter to emphasize vectors pointing in similar directions by varying the saturation of the vector color. The emphasis filtering for the vector space was done on a vector by vector basis. This was done via a function that took the current vector and compared its orientation with that of a target vector. The color was then de-saturated based on the difference between the two orientations passed through a Gaussian function. Figure 7 shows the same set of data as Figures 3 and 6 with both directional vector coloring and emphasis filtering. Implementation visualization package. vtk is available for Windows 95, Windows NT, and several UNIX platforms allowing us to develop on several computers simultaneously. It is built on OpenGL, using hardware display methods where available and MESA otherwise [SCHR96]. The availability of the source code also allowed us to extend the built-in visualization models to implement the directional color model and emphasis filter without having to develop an entire visualization package. It supports real time camera controls within the render window, allowing interactive viewing of the represented objects. vtk comes with C and Tcl bindings, allowing us to embed the visualization capabilities within an easy-to-use interface.

The application we developed allows the user to select which scalar data sets are to be represented and what display method will be used for each. There are controls for scaling and filtering the data. It allows the user to control the coloration of the vectors and whether the emphasis filter is on and what direction is emphasized.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: This project demonstrates some problems associated with visualizing a unique set of data. Standard 2D visualization methods failed to convey all the information accurately. Directly applying standard 3D visualization techniques did not provide efficient exploration tools. By combining standard methods with ones we developed, we provide a visualization tool well suited to sparse vector data with associated scalars. We have also shown the flexibility and power of vtk to perform standard and nonstandard visualizations. Finally, we have introduced a vector coloring filter that allows the isolation of vectors pointing in a particular direction.

div.head: Future directions
div.p: Additional areas for research include expanding the emphasis filter to other data representations, for example using color saturation to emphasize scalar data associated to vectors pointing in a particular direction. The filter could also be extended to emphasize data points with scalar values within a range or that occur within a time period. We also plan to introduce an interactive control for the filter similar to the one discussed by Boring and Pang [BOR96]. A further extension of the control planned is to allow the control point to be moved within the object representation, thus interactively emphasizing vectors pointing at a particular point in 3-space. Radar data of the cloud during the data collection time was also available and we intend to include a representation of the cloud for context.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: We would like to thank Dr. Thomas Marshall for the meterological data and his assistance in interpreting it. Production of this paper was supported by a grant from the National Science Foundation (ASC-9703251).
